Running x86 code on arm is a terrible idea. Apple managed a processor change in the past because powerPC, like arm, is a risc architecture. x86 meanwhile is a cisc architecture.

Basically. An x86 can in theory run arm code near the speed of an actual arm processor because you're more likely to have a situation where one CPU instruction in arm maps to one equivalent CPU instruction in x86.

Meanwhile, an arm chip might have to execute two or more instructions to get the same output a x86 chip would've gotten with a single instruction. Meaning the arm chip needs to run almost twice as fast to keep up.
Don't do it Microsoft! Stay with the X86  platform. Consumers will always turn to Android on ARM. It's a horrible idea to reinvent the wheel.

Since a lot of the reasoning behind x86-64 was to bring RISC like features to x86 such as more general purpose registers, a feature which the ARM instruction set uses heavily for performance. The code generated when building x86-64 rather than x86 produces a lot fewer stack push and pop operations as more values can be held in general purpose registers for longer, and even function parameters can be passed via the general purpose registers. Assuming a JIT recompiler emulator is used, a must for performance when emulating different architectures, this would potentially allow x86-64 to produce more efficient to execute ARM code since fewer stack operations will occur and more ARM registers can be used instead. If there is a significant performance regression it would be ARM32 vs ARM64 or maybe due to SSE2 vector instruction usage rather than x86-64 itself.

Next, part of the claim in this video are wrong. There is nothing inherent about RISC that makes it more power efficient than a CISC, DEPENDING ON workload. Sure, it is true that if a CISC processor happens to have the ideal instruction set to do a particular task, then because of less TRANSISTORS in the supposed RISC, then it could be more efficient than a CISC. Here is the problem though. CISC processors have continually added instruction sets the same way CISC has, so defining RISC and CISC today isn't like it would have been 20 years ago. What that means is, today's RISC could have been CISC 20 years ago.


The X86-64 Instruction set has been refined for about 3 decades, and that's why it rules the desktop market. Not just that, but because multiple companies have been involved with improving it over time. It is a jack-of-all-trades hardware/software architecture, and the ONLY way a company like Apple can compete in some work areas is because of the software development emphasis, but even Apple had to resort to Intel and the X86-64 architecture because their products were lagging behind too much. They are moving away to ARM not because of RISC vs. CISC, because in fact their CPUs will be a combination of both when ARM starts rolling them out. They're hybrids.



The only way to test RISC vs. CISC is to have the SAME company make processors that include both, so that the rest of the CPU architecture is the same. Then you would hit it with a wide variety of work tasks, and then find out where each is faster, along with where each uses less power in completing the ENTIRE task, so power over time duration. And EVEN WITH THIS, you are only testing ONE company's RISC vs. their CISC, so you STILL can't make any empirical statements about it. Compiling and testing software for ARM as well as 32-bit and 64-bit Intel is a huge pain in the ass for developers. I would not expect many to do it. And in addition to the slow-downs and extra battery usage caused by having to emulate x86 on ARM, as well as the ridiculous return to 2GB memory limits which will simply break a lot of modern software by itself, this brings back the early problems of the 32/64-bit divide, where any piece of software that needs to put a DLL into another piece of software (and that is a lot more things than you might think! e.g. context menu items, any kind of hotkey or gesture tool) will not work unless it ships with DLLs for ARM (in addition to x86 and x64, since some processes will still be using those architectures). Fixing 64-bit was a no-brainer when every new machine supported it, and you could also build, test and debug 32-bit code on the very same machine; not the case with ARM. Install sizes will go up, due to needing to ship 3 components instead of 1 for at least some binaries, and developers will have to spend a lot more time building and testing things. It just is not worth it for the small gains ARM offers, at least as things stand. And keep in mind that devs can only support this stuff if they buy expensive ARM laptops for everyone in their teams that needs to work on this. Laptops that aren't good enough to be their main machines, and thus are 100% a cost and not a benefit, other than for supporting ARM, which many resent having to do in the first place. It's a time + money costs that just aren't worth it. Microsoft also have not properly communicated these issues to potential buyers, hoping to trick people into supporting a platform that's really going to cause them pain, and may never get buy-in from developers.
